headline.main: WHEN DEFEAT IS JUST AN ACCENT MARK AWAY

results.snippet: The night before the big day, all the little Spanish spellers were nervous.   Escarlet Cardenas, a fourth grader from Islip, L.I., so feared missing the bus to Albany for the state Spanish Spelling Bee, she kept waking up to check the clock. When...

byline.original: By Michael Winerip, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The night before the big day, all the little Spanish spellers were nervous. Escarlet Cardenas, a fourth grader from Islip, L.I., so feared missing the bus to Albany for the state Spanish Spelling Bee, she kept waking up to check the clock. When it finally was time, 5 A.M., she climbed into the bathtub and fell asleep. Juan Carlos Barahona, the Long Island sixth-grade champ, practiced tricky words for two hours the night before, then went to bed and had a dream. ''All night,'' he told his teacher, Carmen deLopez, ''I dreamed I fought with a monster.''

headline.main: MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY: SPACE CENTER TO BE NAMED AFTER CHALLENGER ASTRONAUT

results.snippet: The president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told graduates at commencement exercises today that the institute's Center for Space Research would be named for Ronald E. McNair, one of the seven astronauts killed Jan. 28 in the...
results.lead_paragraph: The president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told graduates at commencement exercises today that the institute's Center for Space Research would be named for Ronald E. McNair, one of the seven astronauts killed Jan. 28 in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. ''The McNair building will stand as a permanent reminder to future generations at M.I.T. of the grace and significance of extraordinary achievement tempered by an uncommon wisdom and an abiding love of humankind,'' said Paul E. Gray.

headline.main: WHALE RESEARCHERS FIND FRONTIER IN L.I.'S BACKYARD

results.snippet: Sam Sadove and Colleen Coogan clung to the rigging atop Finback II, scanning the white-capped seas for ''footprints,'' birds dancing and ''puffs of smoke.''   Such sightings would indicate the proximity of a giant, the descendant of a creature that...
results.lead_paragraph: Sam Sadove and Colleen Coogan clung to the rigging atop Finback II, scanning the white-capped seas for ''footprints,'' birds dancing and ''puffs of smoke.'' Such sightings would indicate the proximity of a giant, the descendant of a creature that 50 million years ago, for reasons unknown, abandoned the confinement of the land for the boundlessness of the oceans. In fact, despite its presence in lore, literature, metaphor and familiar waters, remarkably little is known about the history and habits of the whale. ''Our knowledge of whales is about equivalent to what we knew about primates 40 years ago,'' said Mr. Sadove, research director of the Okeanos Ocean Research Foundation, based in Hampton Bays.

headline.main: BORMAN TO LEAVE EASTERN

results.snippet: Frank Borman, who led Eastern Air Lines through 16 of its most tumultuous years, said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive officer on June 30 and move to New Mexico, where he will help operate his son's car dealership.  ...
results.lead_paragraph: Frank Borman, who led Eastern Air Lines through 16 of its most tumultuous years, said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive officer on June 30 and move to New Mexico, where he will help operate his son's car dealership. While Mr. Borman will leave what has been one of the hottest seats in the executive suite, he will remain involved in the airline industry as vice chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which is in the process of acquiring Eastern for about $676 million, a move that would create the nation's largest airline. Mr. Borman, 58 years old, said in a statement that after the merger he and his wife, Susan, would move to Las Cruces, N.M., a town about 40 miles north of El Paso, Tex. He told a news conference in Miami that he would work with their son Fred.

headline.main: Public Funeral Service Held for 7th Astronaut

results.snippet: Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force was remembered as a humble hero as he was buried in a Buddhist ceremony Monday. It was the last public funeral service for the seven astronauts killed aboard the space shuttle Challenger.
results.lead_paragraph: Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force was remembered as a humble hero as he was buried in a Buddhist ceremony Monday. It was the last public funeral service for the seven astronauts killed aboard the space shuttle Challenger.

headline.main: KEY NASA ROCKET OFFICIAL QUITS

results.snippet: The head of the Marshall Space Flight Center, which supervises rocket construction for the space agency, said yesterday that he was resigning to make room for a successor who will help redesign the American space program.   The official, William R....
results.lead_paragraph: The head of the Marshall Space Flight Center, which supervises rocket construction for the space agency, said yesterday that he was resigning to make room for a successor who will help redesign the American space program. The official, William R. Lucas, is the highest-ranking member of the space agency to leave his job as a result of the space shuttle disaster. His resignation was the latest in a string of high-level personnel shakeups in recent weeks at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its booster rocket contractor. Management Overhaul Likely Nearly all of the engineers and managers who had key roles in the decision to launch the Challenger have now been shifted to other jobs or have retired. The Challenger was destroyed and its crew of seven were killed when a booster rocket failed shortly after the launching Jan. 28.

headline.main: SCREEN: 'SPACECAMP,' AN UNSCHEDULED TRIP

results.snippet: ''SPACECAMP,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is about a group of teen-agers at a NASA summer camp for aspiring astronauts who take the ultimate unscheduled field trip without parental permission slips. They go to...
results.lead_paragraph: ''SPACECAMP,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is about a group of teen-agers at a NASA summer camp for aspiring astronauts who take the ultimate unscheduled field trip without parental permission slips. They go to outer space. It's all part of a mix-up. Jinx, the appropriately named camp mascot, a literal-minded computer (which, admittedly, hasn't had all its little kinks worked out) overhears a camper idly wishing to be in orbit and arranges to launch him, along with the four other members of his flight team and their astronaut counselor. The situation makes for drama, adventure and lots of questions. Will they make it back? Will they be able to transform themselves from a group of bickering teen-agers to a disciplined crew? Are they capable of making hard adult decisions? And how is NASA ever going to explain all this to their parents?

headline.main: AMID DISPUTES, SHUTTLE PANEL FINALLY FORGED AN AGREEMENT

results.snippet: The chairman of the President's commission on the space shuttle and the only Nobel laureate on the panel were at odds from the beginning. But now, after four months of investigating the Challenger disaster, the 13-member commission has reached a...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the President's commission on the space shuttle and the only Nobel laureate on the panel were at odds from the beginning. But now, after four months of investigating the Challenger disaster, the 13-member commission has reached a remarkable consensus, helped in part by the enormous, steadying influence of the first man to walk on the moon and by a two-star Air Force general. The full story behind the work of the commission, whose report is to be issued Monday, will not be known until all transcripts of secret meetings are made public and the participants have provided full accounts. But interviews conducted in recent days with most of the commissioners shed new light on the individuals and influences that shaped the commission's work. The panel's conduct of the investigation is being hailed by many observers and by most of the commission members. But some commissioners quarreled over whether the final draft was tough enough on the space agency, so it is not unreasonable to suppose there will be criticism from some quarters on this issue.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Apparently Has Heart Attack While Jogging

results.snippet: James B. Irwin, one of a dozen astronauts to walk on the moon, collapsed while jogging Friday, apparently of a heart attack, and was unconscious in critical but stable condition today in Penrose Hospital here, the authorities said.   Doctors said...
results.lead_paragraph: James B. Irwin, one of a dozen astronauts to walk on the moon, collapsed while jogging Friday, apparently of a heart attack, and was unconscious in critical but stable condition today in Penrose Hospital here, the authorities said. Doctors said it would be several days before they could assess his chances for recovery.

headline.main: INSIDER ACCUSATIONS YIELD 5 GUILTY PLEAS

results.snippet: Dennis B. Levine pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he used inside information to make $12.6 million in illegal profits. And he settled S.E.C. civil charges by agreeing to return nearly $11.5 million. In addition, Mr. Levine, a former...
results.lead_paragraph: Dennis B. Levine pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he used inside information to make $12.6 million in illegal profits. And he settled S.E.C. civil charges by agreeing to return nearly $11.5 million. In addition, Mr. Levine, a former investment banker who was accused of insider trading while at several firms, agreed to cooperate with a widening inquiry into the pervasive but ambiguously defined Wall Street practice of leaking information. Mr. Levine, who traded through the Bahamian subsidiary of a Swiss bank, was accused of using such information to trade in the stocks of companies involved in takeovers. Three other young Wall Streeters, and one of their customers, also pleaded guilty to Federal charges in a separate insider trading case. A fifth man, accused of stealing some of the information that was purportedly used in the trades, pleaded not guilty.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Is Better After a Heart Seizure

results.snippet: James B. Irwin, the former astronaut, was awake but ''rather confused'' today, two days after suffering cardiac arrest.   Debi McElvaney, a nursing supervisor at Penrose Hospital, said his condition had been upgraded to serious and stable.
results.lead_paragraph: James B. Irwin, the former astronaut, was awake but ''rather confused'' today, two days after suffering cardiac arrest. Debi McElvaney, a nursing supervisor at Penrose Hospital, said his condition had been upgraded to serious and stable.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS' FAMILIES TELL OF DISMAY

results.snippet: Relatives of the astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster said yesterday that they were dismayed but not surprised by the Presidential commission's findings.   ''We really didn't think there was anything in it we hadn't already heard,'' said...
results.lead_paragraph: Relatives of the astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster said yesterday that they were dismayed but not surprised by the Presidential commission's findings. ''We really didn't think there was anything in it we hadn't already heard,'' said Betty Resnik, Judith Resnik's stepmother. Family members were briefed privately by the commission at a meeting in Washington last week and said in a prepared statement that they would not comment on the report then.

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE FINDINGS: HARSH CRITICISM AND THE REACTIONS
headline.main: A SPACE AGENCY ON DISASTER'S EDGE

results.snippet: In its report to the President, the shuttle panel describes a space agency as on the brink of disaster for months before the 74-second flight of the Challenger, an agency so driven to meet its own schedule that it was increasingly unable to train...

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: In its report to the President, the shuttle panel describes a space agency as on the brink of disaster for months before the 74-second flight of the Challenger, an agency so driven to meet its own schedule that it was increasingly unable to train its crews properly or even find spare parts for its spacecraft. All the while, in its effort to keep the space shuttle cost-effective, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration systematically dismantled the safety and quality control apparatus that were its hallmark throughout the Apollo moon missions, the commission concluded. In part NASA tripped over its own ''can-do'' attitude, the 13 commissioners decided, an attitude of near-infallibility that emboldened the agency to achieve great feats of exploration but poorly prepared it for ''the planning and scheduling discipline required to operate as a 'space truck.' '' Those discoveries, commission members say, suggest that a fatal accident was almost inevitable - and that fixing the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets may prove among the easier tasks as NASA struggles to rebuild its shuttle program. In the course of an intensive but time-constrained 120-day investigation, the Presidential panel uncovered problem after problem, involving both humans and equipment, that seem to defy what one investigator called ''the quick and dirty fix.''

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE FINDINGS: HARSH CRITICISM AND THE REACTONS
headline.main: NASA CHIEF VOWS TO FIX PROBLEMS

results.snippet: Acknowledging that the Rogers Commission's criticisms were ''certainly not entirely undeserved,'' the head of the space agency pledged today to overcome ''our errors,'' overhaul the shuttle management and restore the agency's reputation for safety...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging that the Rogers Commission's criticisms were ''certainly not entirely undeserved,'' the head of the space agency pledged today to overcome ''our errors,'' overhaul the shuttle management and restore the agency's reputation for safety and success. In a statement following the release of the commission's report on the Challenger disaster, James C. Fletcher, the head of the embattled National Aeronautics and Space Administration, declared: ''Where management is weak, we will strengthen it. Where engineering or design or process need improving, we will improve them. Where our internal communications are poor, we will see that they get better.''

headline.kicker: THE SHUTTLE FINDINGS: A LONG SERIES OF FAILURES
headline.main: KEY PORTIONS OF COMMISSION REPORT ON CHALLENGER ACCIDENT

results.snippet: Following are key portions of the text of the summary of the Rogers Commission report on the accident of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, in which the crew of seven astronauts were killed: Preface The accident of space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are key portions of the text of the summary of the Rogers Commission report on the accident of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, in which the crew of seven astronauts were killed: Preface The accident of space shuttle Challenger, mission 51-L, interrupting for a time one of the most productive engineering, scientific and exploratory programs in history, evoked a wide range of deeply felt public responses. There was grief and sadness for the loss of seven brave members of the crew; firm national resolve that those men and women be forever enshrined in the annals of American heroes and a determination, based on that resolve and in their memory, to strengthen the space shuttle program so that this tragic event will become a milestone on the way to achieving the full potential that space offers to mankind. The President, who was moved and troubled by this accident in a very personal way, appointed an independent commission made up of persons not connected with the mission to investigate it. The mandate of the commission was to: 1. Review the circumstances surrounding the accident to establish the probable cause or causes of the accident and 2. Develop recommendations for corrective or other action based upon the commission's findings and determinations.

headline.main: U.S. ACTS TO SPEED RECOMMENDATIONS OF SHUTTLE PANEL

results.snippet: The Reagan Administration is moving quickly to order the space agency to carry out all recommendations of the Presidential commission and not resist any onerous changes and tests even if they might further delay space shuttle flights, senior White...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration is moving quickly to order the space agency to carry out all recommendations of the Presidential commission and not resist any onerous changes and tests even if they might further delay space shuttle flights, senior White House officials said today. President Reagan was described as being ''very positive'' about the work of the commission, headed by William P. Rogers, that investigated the causes of the Challenger disaster last Jan. 28 in which the crew of seven astronauts were killed. The panel attributed the disaster to poorly designed rocket seals and ''serious flaws'' in the space agency's decision-making process.

headline.main: RESHUFFLING AFTER THE SHUTTLE DISASTER

results.snippet: NASA:   Nearly all of the engineers and managers who had key roles in the decision to launch Challenger have now been shifted to other jobs or retired.   DR. WILLIAM R. GRAHAM, 48, acting administrator at the time of the Challenger launching, has...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA: Nearly all of the engineers and managers who had key roles in the decision to launch Challenger have now been shifted to other jobs or retired. DR. WILLIAM R. GRAHAM, 48, acting administrator at the time of the Challenger launching, has resigned and is now awaiting confirmation as President Reagan's science adviser. He was replaced by James C. Fletcher.

headline.main: SCIENTISTS HOPEFUL OF RESTORING CHALLENGER TAPES

results.snippet: Scientists say they have developed a process that they hope can save any voice recordings that might have been made by astronauts in the final seconds of the flight of the space shuttle Challenger, according to space agency officials.   The tapes,...
results.lead_paragraph: Scientists say they have developed a process that they hope can save any voice recordings that might have been made by astronauts in the final seconds of the flight of the space shuttle Challenger, according to space agency officials. The tapes, which were thought to be damaged beyond repair after nearly six weeks' exposure to salt water, are now undergoing a special treatment to reverse the damage. If the process is successful, it could reveal any conversations among the astronauts just before the disaster that destroyed the Challenger and killed its seven-member crew shortly after its launching at Cape Canavaral, Fla., on Jan. 28. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration cautioned in interviews that there were no indications that any such conversations took place in the Challenger's 74-second flight. They added, however, that the new technique would soon let them know for sure.

headline.main: NASA DROPS PLANS TO LAUNCH ROCKET FROM THE SHUTTLE

results.snippet: Because of serious safety concerns, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is abandoning plans to use a rocket fueled with a highly volatile liquid to launch scientific and Defense Department payloads from the space shuttle, officials...
results.lead_paragraph: Because of serious safety concerns, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is abandoning plans to use a rocket fueled with a highly volatile liquid to launch scientific and Defense Department payloads from the space shuttle, officials said yesterday. The decision, a new setback for the shuttle project, threatened further postponements in the nation's stalled program of planetary exploration. Future planetary missions and some large, classified Defense Department satellites will probably be reassigned to launchings by unmanned rockets, officials said. The missions immediately affected are the Galileo spacecraft to explore Jupiter and the European Space Agency's Ulysses spacecraft to orbit and study the Sun. Until the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger last January, they were to have been deployed from shuttles last month and then boosted into interplanetary space by powerful Centaur rockets.

headline.main: EDITORS' NOTE

results.snippet: A picture on Jan. 29, published after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, showed the parents and sister of Christa McAuliffe, the teacher astronaut.

headline.main: ONE OF POP ART'S PIONEERS IS MAKING WAVES AGAIN

results.snippet: James Rosenquist is painting a new mural. It will be 18 feet long and 11 feet high and is to be hung - corporate executives willing - in a communications technology exhibit in the A.T.& T. building at Madison Avenue and 55th Street. Pulling a chair...
results.lead_paragraph: James Rosenquist is painting a new mural. It will be 18 feet long and 11 feet high and is to be hung - corporate executives willing - in a communications technology exhibit in the A.T.& T. building at Madison Avenue and 55th Street. Pulling a chair up to the kitchen table in his spacious Manhattan loft the other day, Mr. Rosenquist excitedly described the work. ''It will be filled with signs and symbols like a kiss mark, a skull and bones, and two people with a thunderbolt between them,'' the artist said, sketching the work on a legal pad. ''It will have ladies of the world - Chinese, African and Caucasian ladies. There will be two parrots and a dog, along with calligraphies in French, Russian, Telugu, Tamil, Indian, Hebrew and Persian. In a two-dimensional surface, I'm trying to show the noise of humanity. ''The parrots and the dog are animals that look like they are attempting to speak,'' he added. ''Man is an animal in a state of evolution, trying to communicate further, and this mural is going into an environment of machines that are trying to help us communicate.''

headline.main: U.S. and Soviet Set '86 Youth Exchange

results.snippet: United States and Soviet officials today announced their countries' first youth exchange program, under which young space enthusiasts will be allowed to visit Moscow and Washington.   The exchange is the first agreed upon by President Reagan the...
results.lead_paragraph: United States and Soviet officials today announced their countries' first youth exchange program, under which young space enthusiasts will be allowed to visit Moscow and Washington. The exchange is the first agreed upon by President Reagan the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their meeting in Geneva in November 1985.
